Script: For decades, software had been defined by its graphical user interface.
The GUI transformed computing from a niche skill into a globally accessible resource.
And it empowered billions of users, but with a hidden design cost.
VisualDescription: Montage of early computers with command lines.
Transition to modern devices with colorful GUIs.
Crowds of diverse people using phones and laptops.

Script: Meanwhile, behind the scenes, a quiet shift was occurring.
Graphic artists, once central to design, were pushed aside.
Art-first gave way to code-first, which eventually became code-only.
VisualDescription: Split screen: artist sketching GUI form, buttons, labels, and textboxes on paper vs. developer typing code.
Sketch fades out, leaving only scrolling XAML.
Artistâ€™s tools dissolve into lines of markup.

Script: Framework publishers promised visual editors would come...
But previews lagged, broke, or misled the public.
What was still known as design was really only a wall of cryptic text,
instead of the visual canvas everyone had been promised.
VisualDescription: Salesperson promising features that would never come.
Code scrolling endlessly in background.
Canvas locked behind glass, unreachable.
Scenes.CameraDirections: Fast cuts, glitch effects, overlay of broken previews.

Script: Today, even when visual editing is offered in tiny, specialized
enclaves, it remains chained to rigid structures.
Because all of GUI design intent is now lost in containers and hierarchies.
VisualDescription: Artist dragging shapes on canvas.
Shapes snap back into rigid boxes.
Chains wrap around the canvas, symbolizing constraint.
Scenes.CameraDirections: Symbolic animation, medium shots of canvas.

Script: This inversion disqualifies true graphic designers,
completely replacing visual composition with textual coding.
And in the process, it alienates the very people who know how
to make interfaces that appeal to human beings.
VisualDescription: Artist fades into background.
Engineer dominates screen with code.
Users look confused at sterile, lifeless interfaces.
Scenes.CameraDirections: Slow fade transitions, muted color palette.

Script: Visual liberation means returning power to artists.
It means starting and working with a blank visual canvas, instead of a data tree.
It also means design before structure, and expression over syntax.
VisualDescription: Canvas opens, glowing with vibrant colors.
Artist paints freely, shapes flow naturally.
Interfaces emerge organically from visual ideas.

Script: Small developers deserve tools that respect artistry.
And graphic artists deserve the freedom to create visually.
While users deserve intuitive interfaces actually born of human imagination.
VisualDescription: Indie developers collaborating with artists.
Interfaces forming from sketches into polished GUIs.
Smiling users interacting with intuitive designs.
Scenes.CameraDirections: Montage of collaboration, close-ups of joyful faces.

Script: The future of software is not code-only.
It is visual liberation.
It is artistry restored.
Follow us on GitHub to find out how Implied Form Design in SvgTools will
help to solve this problem.
VisualDescription: Final logo animation: 'Visual Liberation'.
Canvas bursts into radiant light.
Tagline: 'Design First, Code Automatically with Implied Form Design'
Scenes.CameraDirections: Cinematic closing shot, fade to white.
